Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Addition of High Performance Computers for the Molecular Education and Research Consortium in Undergraduate Computational ChemistRY (MERCURY)
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award Professor George Shields from Bucknell University and colleagues Marc Zimmer (Connecticut College), Carol Parish (University of Richmond) and Maria Gomez (Mount Holyoke College) have acquired a computer cluster to be shared by a large consortium of primarily undergraduate universities and colleges referred to as MERCURY (Molecular Education and Research Consortium in Undergraduate computational ChemistRY). The cluster is used in computational chemistry research projects. These projects employ theoretical chemistry programs and algorithms or processes using principles from quantum mechanics or molecular mechanics (often called molecular dynamics simulations). The computations are used to predict and understand a wide range of properties of molecules such as their acidity, chemical reaction mechanisms such as those that lead to the production of tropospheric ozone and hydroxyl radicals, biochemistry questions such as the binding of small molecules to proteins and even the study of environmental problems such as the chemistry of steroids that are common contaminants in surface and wastewater. The consortium involves 27 computational chemists from 24 primarily undergraduate institutions. The acquisition has a broad impact on the training of undergraduate research students who are incorporated into the workforce or those who attend graduate and professional schools.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research in areas such as those described above. Further examples include: (a) studies of defect conduction paths with applications to fuel cells, (b) understanding the molecular behavior of model compounds such as polyradicals, and elucidating biomolecular dynamics and bond making and breaking reactions, (c) computations to understand the photophysics of light-producing and light-detecting proteins, (d) studies of the conformations of small peptides and other important areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Involvement in a highly mentored, exciting undergraduate research project is the key to cultivating and retaining student interest in the sciences and is therefore an excellent means for increasing both the number of students who intend to have careers in science, as well as the diversity of the science community. This grant funded computer hardware that allowed the 27 MERCURY faculty to expand undergraduate research opportunities to students at their institutions, and enabled students from other institutions to participate in this scientifically-rich and collegial consortium.

Intellectual Merit: 

The intellectual merits of this proposal were: 1.) The creativity and diversity of the research of the MERCURY faculty are strong and have proven to be highly suitable for meaningful undergraduate participation 2.) The record of productivity achieved by the consortia faculty and their undergraduate co-workers is high; and, 3.) The level of computational resources and methodological tools available for the projects continued to be state-of-the art with the additional computer resources. Approximately half of our graduates attended graduate school for the purpose of obtaining advanced degrees in STEM fields and approximately 3/4 are female and/or minority. Since the start of the MERCURY consortium students mentored by MERCURY faculty have won more than 50 national awards, including a Rhodes, 10 Fulbright Fellowships,21 Goldwater Fellowships, two Gates Cambridge Scholarships, and more than 20 national graduate fellowships (NSF, NDSEG, NASA). 

Broader Impacts: 

The broader impacts of the proposed activity were: 1.) A significant number of students from groups traditionally underrepresented in chemistry, including women and minority students had the opportunity to work side-by-side with faculty on meaningful research projects in highly mentored research environments; 2.) Undergraduate students received and benefited from intensive training in computational chemistry, and, from this experience, developed skill sets that will serve them well in their scientific careers, and, 3.) Approximately half of the students who work on these projects with go on for further graduate work in STEM fields. 

Overall, during the 2016-19 grant period we worked with 325 undergraduates, and 75% were female and/or students of color. In addition, 8 high school students, 2 post-baccalaureate fellows, 3 master’s students, 2 post-doctoral researchers, and a staff research scientist worked with the MERCURY investigators. We published 123 peer-reviewed papers, or 1.52 papers/faculty/year, two technical books, and 11 book chapters. We held four successful conferences, averaged 102 attendees with an average of 52.5 undergraduate poster presentations. Of our 24 speakers, 16 were female and/or faculty of color.  The research productivity of the 27 MERCURY faculty was particularly high, as they published at three times the rate of faculty in the physical sciences at predominantly undergraduate institutions.
